div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express Steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wedensday for Port Sudan (and Suakin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe service to Kharteum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.
For freight or passage apply the Co.'s agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, or for passage only to THOS, COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE, REISE-BUREAT or other Tourist Agenecies.

div.head: First Cirole of Irrigation
div.p: Owing to repairs in course of execution to the gates of Bahr Moes bead lock, navigation will be interrupted in that canal from now to March 15th

div.head: War Office Tenders
div.p: The date of opening the ... at the contract for building repairs and supply of building material in the Cairo district during 1908, fixed for the 27th January 1908, has now been altered to the 28th January.

div.head: Flats for Officials.
div.p: The Heliopolis Co, has contracted with the Government to build annually 100 flats or villas to be let at low rentals to Government officials. This contract is to continue for four years. Should the accommodation not be taken up by the officials the general public will be able to profit by the occasion.

div.head: The '‘Carmanla
div.p: The triple screw turbine SS. “Carmanla of the Cunard Line, 20,000 tons, is due here on the 2nd February with a large number of tourists from America. This is her first visit to this port. On her way back to New York she calls at Fiume, the seaport of Hungary and at Naples, and affords an excellent opportunity tor all those who are not in a hurry to get home

div.head: Ports and Lights Scandals
div.p: The Finance Ministry bas published an offi- cial notice to the Attieh Etendi Ghirgis, of the Ports and Lights Adimimistra- tion, has been dismissed for irregularities by a decision of a Council of Discipline and that& the Minister of Finance has approved of this decision, which will take effect as from the 4th August last

div.head: Mr. Blunt on Alexandrians
div.p: corresponden’ writes to ask, what were the disparaging remarks made by Mr Wiltrid Blunt on Mr. Moberly Bell and on Alexandrian people in general, to which Mr Cornish took exception to in our issue of Saturday Inst. The following is the offending paragraph —"He was born, I believe, at Alexandria, the sun of & British subject established there in business... His connection however with the country has always been that of the alien Levantine society of which he was a member a society which in Alexandria, more than any where else lives far removed from the higher life of native Egypt, having its dealings only with the parasites of Western civilization and judging all native things according to the standards of the Stock Exchange."

div.head: THE SEASON AT HELOUAN
div.p: Despite the fact that the season so far has Not been any means so successful as that of last year, there has been a great influx of visitors during the past few days, and it would seem that after all the arrival of the usual numbers who yearly visit) Egypt bas been delayed rather than abandoned. Helouan at least has no cause for complaint, for al the hotels are doing capital business, and every day brings fresh arrivals The first dance give by any of the hotels in the town was held last week at the Tewfik Palace Hotel when the ball room was well filled, and the ... given last night at the Grand Hotel, also attract ed many visitors. The Al Hayat, which is really a town in itself while the smaller hotels of the place are also very well patronized. The evident popularity of this resort might almost, we would have imagined, induce the authorities to at least consider the many and pressing needs of the town to which we alluded in a recent issue, but perhaps the Tanzim are to be forgiven their apathy in this respect, for we tremble to think of the feelings which would be expressed in Cairo should the suburb of Helouan be accorded the attention which is denied to the capital, and after all change is necessary to man, and as long as the present order of things obtain we are not likely to be without it. For by the time that one is weary of the dust, a drenching shower has converted it into mud and slush Every thing changes — except the ... ence of the Tanzim to the needs if the towns under its jurisdiction. A most successful dance, the second one of the season, was held at the Helouan Casino on Thursday evening, the hall of the Casino being well filled with dancers, many of whom had jour- neyed out to Helouan from Cairo for the occasion. The hall is as well suited to dancing as it is to the theatrical performances to which it is usually devoted, indeed, the Casino and all its works have been an assured and remark able success from the day of inauguration, and are proving a boon to the inhabitants of Helouan, for the programme of entertarnment ie varied and always good and the theatre hall is one of the most comfortable in Cairo or its vicinity. Central by situated within a minutes walk of the railway station, and within easy access of the hotels it supplies a long felt want. Military band performances are given in the gardens during the afternoons three times a week, while orchestral, cinematograph, and theatrical performances are also given regular- ly in the Casino itself. Frequent trains run to and from the Bab el Louk station in Cairo, and Helouan is fast becoming what San Stefano is to Alexandria, the resort of pleasure

div.head: INSERT AD HERE, Berlitz Schools of laungages
TEMPESTUOUS WEATHER MANY CRAFTS WRECKED PIERCE HURRICANE
div.p: Alexandria has for the past thirty six hours heen visited by one of the most violent gales ever known since meteorological observations were begun here, Saturday afternoon was as time as could be wished and the sky gave no Signs of the terrible weather that was impend- ing. At 7pm. the rain began to fall and in half an hours time a perfect deluge of rain came down Shortly afterwards a thunderbolt fell in the neighborhood of Ibrahimieh and its passage through the air was extraordinarily vivid On its way earthwards it came down Like a brilliant streak of flame and its fiery course was visible miles away. Immediately afterwards huge crashes of thunder resounded snd the rain redoubled in vigour. Throughout the night the storm showed no sign of lessening and indeed grew in strength 1 the wind yesterday reached a rate of one hundred and twenty kilometers the hour. The records at the Meteorological Station at Napoleon for the past: twenty years slows that the wind has attained a speed of ninety to a hundred kilometers per hour, But the force of the wind yesterday has never during that period been equalled, Yesterday afternoon was extraordinarily boisterous and the hurricane grew in violence. The rain and Wind came down in powerful angry gusts and all the streets were utterly deserted. About midday yesterday a hail storm of excessive severity burst over the town. The hail stones came down in such quantities and were of so large a size that in a few minutes the streets were covered in a mantle of white
The sea was very rough and many of the hips in the harbour got adrift) and dragged their anchors

In the afternoon an Ottoman sailing vessel from Australia under the command of Captain Macah Papalion with a cargo of wood consign ed to Rostow Bey to the value of about £1,000 was driven into Eastern barbour. Drop ping her anchor in a dangerous position about half past two she was only able to withstand quarter of an hours bulleting Torn away From her anchorage she was driven sheer on to The rocks and after a little more than two hours was a broken up wreck. The crew manag ed to escape in a boat and after a hard struggle with the elements were safely landed thanks to the assistance of a crew who went out to them. Last night a small private tug broke away from her moorings and is now a wreck, A coast guard rowing boat was dashed to pieces against the petroleum quay, and several light- ers in harbour have been sunk. The wreck of the Greek brig once again demonstrates the absolute necessity of a life boat service at Alex- andria quays were lined with hundreds Of people who in spite of the terrible weather, watched the vessel being dashed about before their eyes.

The storm has uprooted great numbers of trees it the neighborhood of Alexandria, About fifty trees in the Rosetta Road between Rosetta Gate and San Stefano have been torn from their roots. ‘Tis an ill wind that blows nobody good and large numbers of gigantic and inartistic advertisements, that have dis figured lather to the Ramleh Road, are now lying prone on the ground.

The have wrought on the roofs of build ings has been considerable. A chimney on the house of Mr Charles Alderson at Bulkeley was blown down and fell the roof of the kit- chen, which was ripped off, and the contents of the kitchen destroyed and two Arabs buried among the ruins.

They were extracted without any serious injuries. As soot the news of this accident reached the Alexandria Police they telephoned the Fire Brigade, who were on the spot half our after the catastrophe. The new fire brigade motor cat was seriously impeded, as the ... to get down and hack a way for the ... through the masses of fallen trees. When the fire brigade arrived at Mr. Alderson's home, there was no need for their services for the men had been rescued from the ruins in time and were being attended by the Ramleh Mitkav doctor.

They were extracted without any serious injuries. As soot the news of this accident reached the Alexandria Police they telephoned the Fire Brigade, who were on the spot half our after the catastrophe. The new fire brigade motor cat was seriously impeded, as the ... to get down and hack a way for the ... through the masses of fallen trees. When the fire brigade arrived at Mr. Alderson's home, there was no need for their services for the men had been rescued from the ruins in time and were being attended by the Ramleh Mitkav doctor.
At ... a house that was being destroy Ed by order of the municipality was blown on to the adjoining house and both toppled down Fortunately nobody was injured.
The stable of a native notable near San Stefano was struck by lightning last night and a valuable horse killed
A tramway car was blown right over on the Ramleh line near the Khediviah Mother's Palace. Nobody was injured.

Three horses were killed between the Rond Point by the Alexandria Water Company pumping station and the line to Cairo. The horses were killed by a naked electric wire used as a feeder for the Alexandria Tramway Company's system at the Rond Point. If the pecuniary damages, which this Company has already had to pay for similar accidents at this point has not already shown it the neces sity of replacing this naked wire by an ander ground cable, it is strange that the Municipal ity should so far have neglected its duty in not reminding the company of the fact.

Telegraphic communication with other parts of the country has been entirely cut off by the land-lines, with the exception of a single line which can only work at half its normal rate. Recourse has therefore to be had to the cables of the ETC and to reach Suez it is necessary at present to circuit the continent.
At half past nine this morning the black flag was hoisted at Kom el Nadoura to prohibit the entrance or exit of all ships

div.head: Our Cairo Correspondent writes:
div.p: Our Cairo Correspondent writes: Sanday morning broke in a deluge of rain accompanied by an icy wind, in Cairo, and a steady down pour continued for the whole of the forenoon. Little rain fell in the afternoon, but the cold was as severe as ever, and towards nightfall a half gale sprang up, quickly clearing the streets of pedestrians who were not compelled to remain abroad. The cab stands were practic- ally empty, the drivers evidently preferring to run the risk of losing possible fares, to the certainty of being half frozen on their boxes. Despite the crowds of men and boys engaged upon the clearing of mud from the principal streets, they were, as usual, almost impassible, though it must be admitted that they were preferable to the pavements which were carefully avoided by any but the most callous of the foot passengers.
Our Suez Correspondent writing yesterday says: -
Since daybreak this morning a S. W. gale has been raging at Suez, and the steamers in the roads experience difficulties in discharging their cargoes.
Owing to the strong wind, the 8.8. “Bute- shire” grounded in the Canal near station kilo- metre 157 but came off without assistance.
The Dutch steamer "Goentoer” is as well ashore in the small lake, and is blocking the passage of steamers.
The Mail steamers “Oceana, and “Omrah” are entering the Canal this evening, followed by the “Armiston,” “Clau Fraser,” “Chau Macin- tosh” “R. Rubatino,” “Enna” and Dutch crui- ser “Zeland."

div.head: ACCIDENT TO AUSTRIAN LLOYD STEAMER
div.p: The Anstrian Lloyd SS. “Cleopatra,” (Captain Ivenich), which left Alexandria at 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon for Brindisi and Trieste, had to return shortly afterwards owing to meeting with a mishap in the New Pass. The “Cleopatra” and her captain have been on the regular express service of the Austrian Lloyd between Alexandria and Trieste for years past and the Captain bears a high reputation for navigation and caution As there were many ships passing through the Old Pass, it was decided to take the New Pass. The pilot left the steamer, as usual, before entering the Pass. The steamer when in the Pass struck against a rock, which made a 1ole in her hold, number one. The water rushed in with great force and filled the hold. The captain decided therefore to turn back, al- hough there was no danger as the system of watertight compartments acted excellently. The “Cleopatra” came back into harbour at 5.30 pm and the work of discharging cargo rom No. 1 hold was at once begun. The damaged cargo is as follows : two hundred bales of cotton, sixteen cases of skins and seven hundred and forty two empty casks. The loss s insignificant. The steamer will be taken o the dry dock at Gabbari, as soon as the ‘weather improves. There were sixty-five pas- engers on board. The mail was transferred to the train, which left Alexandria yesterday afternoon with the Brindisi mail.
The “Cleopatra” up to going to press is still in harbour as she cannot get to the dry dock owing to the gale

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive was present on Saturday at Ab- lin Palace and received in audience the Minis- ters, M. de Martino the newly appointed Con sul General and Diplomatic Agent of Italy, Herbert Bey, Prince Hussein Kamel Pasha and Sir Ernest Cassel

div.head: SIR ELDON CORST
div.p: Our Sohag correspondent writes :-

The steamer with Sir E. Gorst arrived at Sohag at 3.30 p.m. on Monday. Sir Eldon first visited the Irrigation Department, and then all the other Government offices escorted by a body of cavalry and the commander of the police. Sir Eldon was much pleased with the excellent arrangements made by the energetic Mudir. After that he visited Basta Bey’s school, which was beautifully decorated with flags, flowers, and palms on the occasion of Sir Eldon Gorst’s visit. For the hundred yards leading to the school the four hundred and fifty pupils stood on either side cheering their illustrious visitor as he approached the school gate

As soon as be alighted, the Mudir introduc- ed to him Mr. H. Basta, A.M.I.C.E, and Mr. S. Basta, sons of the late founder, also the headmaster. Sir Eldon then in spected the school rooms asking the head- master for much information concerning it, which the latter was only too pleased to answer. Then a pupil delivered a speech in English which pleased Sir Eldon so mach that he graciously asked the pupil to let him have it. Finally a body of scholars sang “God save the King” in an admirable manner, Sir Eldon holding his hat in his hand all the time. On leav- ing Sir Eldon thanked the founder's sons, who take great interest in the school and support it financially, also the headmaster and teachers for their conscientious labours in instructing their scholars.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The SS. “Cairo” left Marseilles on Saturday land is due here on Wednesday at daybreak
The 8.8. “Sailor Prince,” with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 23rd inst and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Wednes- day.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISES. THE RUSH TO LIQUIDATE
div.p: Among the many new companies floated last year, who are now eager to go into liqui- dation, is the Egyptian Economical Residences Company, which will hold an extraordinary meeting this afternoon at Cairo to consider that question of the dissolution of the company.

The shareholders of the Commercial Indus- trial and Land Company of Egypt Limited have been summoned to meet on the 6th Feb- ruary to consider the voluntary winding up of the Company. The directors of the Company are against this policy and we beg to call the attention of our readers to a notice addressed to the shareholders, which appears in our advertising columns to-day
The date for the adjourned meeting of the Cairo Estates Limited, when the question of that company’s liquidation, will be decided on, will be announced shortly.

div.head: FOR SUFFERERS FROM THE CRISIS.
div.p: In these troublous times when so many persons are suffering physically as well as Financially from the crisis, it is interesting to now that a special cure for persons whose nerves want calming, has been instituted in this city. We are ashamed to avow that we have never beard of the “Blue Chamber” here at the Paris “Figaro” vouches for it and the information has been copied by many London newspapers. The following is what the “Figaro” says :-

“Experiments have been made from to time to test the effect of colour on the sick, especially on those suffering from nervous afflictions and mental disorders. In an institution at Alex- andria, where the rooms have been fitted up with coloured glass, it is found that in a blue chamber a restless person has been calmed ; in red chamber a person suffering from melan- holia, with a tendency to suicide, has become gay, and in a violet chamber a maniac has become sane.”
The following is the text of a letter addressed to the Financial Adviser: -
Sir,

With regard to the appeal which has been made to you by some of the financial notabili ties of Cairo with a view to relieve the land and house owners from the prejudicial effect of the crisis which has fallen on the country, I beg to submit for your kind and earnest consi deration, the following remarks in the interest of the mass of the people
In my opinion based on discussion with intelligent people of various classes and especially with native land owners the Govern- ment ought not to guarantee any loan except on the following conditions

1st. That the Credit Foncier Egyptien who is to be trusted with this work should use half of the funds guaranteed by the Government and lent to him for loans under one thousand pounds and over three hundred ; one quarter for loans under two thousand pounds and over one thousand ; and the rest under five thous- and and over two thousand

2nd. That the rate of interest charged by the credit Foncier should not be over 6% in case the loan is obtained at 4% and in any case should not exceed two per cent over the rate of interest charged for the money guaranteed by the government whatever may be the amount of the loan
3rd. That every person should not obtain more than one loan from the Government guaranteed fund and on the condition that he should not have obtained in 1908 a loan from non guaranteed funds

4th. Should the Credit Foncier refuse to fellow these conditions the Government could| take the matter in band by creating a special Department for this purpose and profiting from the difference in the rate of interest which not only will cover the expenditure but will also leave an important surplus.

The Government has already helped the credit Foncier by lending them half a million of pounds but I have beard from reliable sources that the greatest part of this sum has been lent to rich people so that the relief instead of falling to the lot of the relatively poor and middle classes has gone to strengthen the position of the rich who with a little sacrifice could hold their own and save their poorer and less favored fellow creatures from certain ruin.
I am convinced that the able hands that direct the destinies of this country will not permit the interests of the millions being sacri- ficed for those of the millionaires.
I have the honor to remain, Sir, Your most obedient servant NEGHIB SHAKRA. Advocate. Proprietor and Editor the legal and judicial review of ‘“Al-Istiklal.”
Cairo, January 22.

div.head: CUNARD LINE.
div.p: For passengers returning from Egypt in March, particular attention 1s drawn to the sailing of the “Caronia,” which leaves Alex andria on 7TH March and calls at Naples. This offers the choice of a water trip or an overland journey to Liverpool where pas- sage to New York may be secured on the Cunard North Atlantic service which in- cludes the largest and fastest steamships in the world. 31819-16*-2

div.head: Insert Ad here for new khedive hotel
OBITUARY.
BIMBASHI REUFEE
div.p: There went to its long eternal rest yesterday the soul of Bimbashi P. H. Renfee. Its passing was of a supremely tragic character. In full pos- session of all bis facilities, the “Major,” as he was termed amongst his many intimates, was playing billiards in the well known saloon of Shepbeard’s Hotel at half past six on Saturday evening, when he suddenly complained of giddiness, and relinquished the game. He was immediately attended to by Doctor Brabant, land taken to a room in the hotel, where he exhibited most serious symptoms. Other doc tors were called, and, in consultation with Doctor Brabant, the consensus of opinion was that the patient was suffering from hemorrhage on the brain. The four doctors in attendance did all that was possible, and the condition of the patient becoming worse, it was decided to transport him to the Deaconesses’ Hospital Here he never recovered from the state of coma into which he had fallen, and passed away yesterday morning at five o'clock.

Bimbashi Reufee had experience of much active work in the field, and possessed many medals with clasps for services rendered in Egypt and elsewhere. He was one of the first to enter Cairo after the decisive en- counter with Arabi Pasha's troops at Tel el- Kebir. For many years he was associated with the Police Force in Alexandria and subsequently Cairo. His assiduous and con scientious labours ultimately resulted in his being appointed Governor of the Ghizeh Prison, whence he was transferred to the great central prison of Menshieh, as director, — a posi tion he held at the moment of his untimely death.

The funeral took place from the Deavonesses’ Hospital at four yesterday afternoon, the service in the new cemetery being conducted by the Chaplain to the Forces. There was present at the mournful ceremony a vast number of sympathizers, and many beautiful wreaths were sent The cemetery was thronged, land it is quite impossible to give the names of fall present, but we noticed on the cards attached to the floral tributes the names of H.EB. Coles Pasha and colleagues at the Central office of the Prison’s Administration, Officials of the Central Office Staff, Mr. Edward Dicey, C B, Mr. Felix E. Powell, Mr. and Mrs H.W. Tite, Mr. and Mrs, B.A.P. Schreiber, Mr. Richard Marburg, Mr. R. Diacono representing the Hamburg and Anglo American Nile Company, Mr. H. Hope, Mr. Adam Scheuber, M. D., Mr and Lady Valda Machell, Mr. and Mrs. J.K.C. Braun, Ibrahim Bey Hilmy, Mr. J. L Preston, Count Geraldo Petracohi, Mr. Baumgarteo, Mr. Henry Re nonard, Mr. Adelbert de Hebentanz, M.D., Mr. Oscar Flood representing Shepheard’s Hotel, and there was a pretty wreath dedicated to the memory of the lamented gentleman by the staff of Shepheard’s Hotel.
On behalf of our readers, we tender Mrs Reufee our heartfelt sympathy in this her great and irreparable loss.
The following special order was issued yes terday by the Ministry of the Interior
“It is with great regret that the Inspector General announces the death of Bimbashi Reufee, Director of the Cairo Prison, which occurred at Cairo on the 26th instant
“Bimbashi Reufee joined the Prisons Depart ment in 1897, and has largely assisted in the reforms introduced into the Prisons service during the past ten years.
“Prior to entering the Prisons Department, Bimbashi Reutee was for many years in the Police service and on more than one occasion showed considerable coolness and courage in the discharge of his duty
“By the death of Bimbashi Reufee, the Egyptian Government bas lost the services of an officer of considerable ability and expe rence.”

div.head: BUURSE AND BANKING CO
div.p: This morning the application by a share holder, for the removal of the liquidator and the appointment of another, came on for hear ing at the British Consular Court, Alexandria The case for plaintiff was argued by Mr Reginald Silley, with whom was Mr. Gooding At the close of the argument Mr. Whitworth, for the defendant, asked for an adjournment until Monday next in order to allow time to consider and meet the affidavits filed by plaintiff. Plaintiffs counsel opposed adjourn ment and said that defendant's counsel should be called upon at once to reply
Finally the court adjourned the case until Thursday at 10 o'clock
A full report of the extraordinary general meeting of this company on Saturday last will be found on page 6 of to-day’s issue

div.head: THE ESNEH BARRAGE
div.p: On Friday afternoon Fakhry Pasha, Mi- nister of Public Works, laid the key stone in the first arch of the Esneh barrage. His Excellency expressed himself as greatly pleased with the progress of the work.

PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Milner accompanied by Mr. George Biddulpb, both of whom are Directors of the Bank of Egypt, are due to arrive at Alex- andria, per the 8.8. “Cairo.”
The Countess of Rothes is now staying at the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, the Earl of Rothes having left Khartoum on the 14th instant accompanied by Mr. Crighton for a shooting expedition up the Blue Nile

The Earl of Kingston, who was so success- ful on his shooting trip last year, has again left Khartoom in quest of big game. He bas been joined by Sir Robert Harvey and the party is now on its way up the White Nile in la private steamer.

The father of the British Diplomatic Agent, Sir John Gorst, has written, and Sir Isaac Pitman and Sons will shortly publish, a book f Recollections called ‘New Zealand Revisited.’ in 1906 Sir John was invited by the British Government to represent it at the opening of the International Exhibition at Christ Church, New Zealand. This was his second visit to the colony. The first was in the early sixties, the period immediately preceding the outbreak of the Maori War, when he first served in an official capacity as Commissioner of Waikato under Sir George Grey. Naturally, his recent visit suggested contrasts between old and new conditions.
After Sir Ernest Cassel leaves Egypt he will probably go to Biarritz with his son in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Ashley, where Sir Ernest has a villa.
Sir Robert Hay-Drummond Hay, H.B.M. Consul General at Beyrout, has arrived at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo.

It is stated that Hassan Radwan Pasha the Moudir of the Sharkieb province will shortly retire on pension and that Abdul Khbalik Pasha Sarwat the Moudir of Assiout will replace him There will be many transfers and promotions among the Modir and the Sub- mudirs,
Mr. F. Mackinnon, managing director of the Clayton Gas Co. of Egypt, Ltd., has left for Tor to superintend the installation of the disinfecting apparatus there.

div.head: THE LUXOR GYMKHANA
div.p: (From our own CORRESPONDENT)
Luxor, 24th January.
The fourth gymkhana of the season arranged by the Luxor Sporting Club took place yes- terday in perfect weather and was attended »y many visitors from the Winter Palace and Luxor Hotels.

A native race in which the competitors had to race in sacks was the first event and one of he most amusing. This was followed by a native water carriers race, and the third gave the donkey boys an opportunity of showing of the speed limit of their patient little beasts.

Ladies and gentleman entired for the fourth event, also a donkey race and here the steamer Rameses had it all its own way for Miss Percival one of the passengers came in first and the ships doctor second. Miss Percival was mounted on a well-known Luxor donkey thal holds the record as a racer and carried Mr. Schaetzle to victory at the last meeting.

Miss Parsons who is staying at the Winter Palace won the variety race in which the riders had to pick up goolahs on long sticks provided for the purpose on their way to the winning post This is s proceeding which requires dexterity and to which the donkeys often object
The three last items on the programme were a buffalo, horse, and camel races for natives of which the first was the funniest, the antics of the, uncouth clumsy beasts arousing much laughter
Mr Scheich, the popular manager of the Winter Palace Hotel, and Mr. Saville acted las judges.
The meeting was generally voted a success land the proceeds as usual were given to that most deserving institution, the Luxor hospital tor natives

div.head: FAYOUM RACING CLUB
div.p: The 3rd meeting for the races organized by the “Fayoum Racing Club” will take place next Friday on the course at Fayoum. It will be the most important of the season.
After the six events on the programme there will be a Bergas organized by the Hawariehs of Guirgueh on_ the invitation of the Mudir.
All who wish to attend this meeting can leave Cairo and return the same day at 8.45 p.m.

div.head: Isert ad for military tailors here
FRANCE AND MOROCCO. THE DEBATE IN THE CHAMBER

div.p: Chamber of Deputies. The debate on the interpellations of M.M. Janrés and Ribot opposing farther penetration by France in Morocco was notable by the reappearance of M. Delcassé, who admitted full responsibility for the Murocean policy of France in view of the danger of another power establishing her influepce at Fez. For this reason, he said, he had promoted ententes with Italy, Spain, and Great Britain and induced Russia to shake hands with Great Britain. Germany, envious and angry at the shifting of the balance of power in Europe, had threatened war at the time of the Algeciras Conference, but no war had resulted because of the danger of attacking France with her powerful allies and friends. He urged the necessity of defending the approaches to France's African Empire, on which her future depended. M. Delcass¢ receiv- ed an ovation. The debate has been adjourned ( Reuter )

All the European Press comments on the statement made by M. Delcassé yesterday in the Chamber, defending bis policy in Morocco and vauntiog the alliances and friendships, which have strengthened the situation of France, who ought to have an army in conse quence. The “Temps” denies the news that Sultan Abd-el-Aziz has asked the great Powers, and especially Germany, to make France stop its military operations beyond » seven mile rune fixed by the Algeciras Confeience ( Havas

M. Delcassé is the absorbing topr of Frerci: Parliamentarians. He is generally regarded as expressing the real views of the majority The “Journal des Débats” strikes one discordant pote declaring that M. Deccassé was inep portune. The German press reserves comment, being confident of reassuring speechs by M. Cle mencau and M. Pichon. It ‘Seclares that the network of M. Delcassé’s alliances was anited solely through hatred of Germany (Renter)

div.head: A PLOT IN LISBON.
div.p: There are numerous rumours regarding 4 revolutionary plot, but it is officially declared that the Government is able to maintain order ( Reuter )
Lisbon, January 26

The plotters unsuccessfully attempted to disaffect the troops. Quantities of weapons have been seized. The troops are confined to barracks. Senor Franco's house is guarded tor fear of an outrage. (Reuter)

div.head: LABOUR TROUBLES IN ENGLAND.
div.p: A conflict took place in Birmingham between the unemployed, who are marching from Man Chester to London, and the police. The latter escorted them to the city boundary. Several arrests were made. ( Reuter )

div.head: THE LICENSING BILL
div.p: The Cabinet has decided to give Mr. Asquith charge of the Licensing Bill. It is expected that a “casus-belli” with the Lords will arise out of the Education Bill. ( Reuter

div.head: FIGHT AT CASABLANCA.
div.p: Three tribes attacked the French force north of Casablanca but were repulsed after a 4 hours’ fight. The French had 6 wounded (Reuter)

div.head: DEATH OF “OUIDA".
div.p: The novelist Miss Ouida is dead. ( Reuter )

The Abyssinian mission of General Meshesha to the Sublime Porte has failed. In spite of the partial satisfaction granted by the Imperial Government, which has recognized the Abyssi nian’s right of admission to the Dair Sultaneh Convent through a door giving admission to the upper part. The General insisted on all the keys being put in the hands of the Abyssinian monks. The Government replied to this by an absolute refusal, declaring that the statutes established by Sultan Mahmoud could not be changed. The Government is beginning to show signs of weariness at the prolonged stay of the Abyssinian mission, which is lodged in one of the largest hotels of Constantinople at the expense of the Government. It is said that their stay has already cost the Treasury over £7,000. As the Abyssinians do not show any desire to leave Constantinople the authorities have withdrawn the Mihmanderé, who has been attached to the General as guide and interpreter.

The second Abyssinian delegate, Nagadras Behabtié, who is also Goverdor of Harrar, has left Constantinople with four members of the mission, on his way to Jerusalem, whence he will return to his own country. But General Meshesha chief of the mission, with a secre tary interpreter is still here in order to pursue His claims. In ,regard to these claims he has just presented a fresh note to the Sublime Porte But itis not believed that the General will be successful in inducing the Imperial Government to modify its views, which are based on the maintainance of the ecclesiastical status quo in the Holy Places

div.head: TURKEY AND PRINCE FIRMA.
div.p: According to a telegram received from Tabriz the Turkish commander bas peremptori ly ordered Prince Firinan Pirma to leave Soj bulak, saying that it was in Turkish territory Reuter

div.head: SOCIALISM IN ENGLAND.
div.p: It is expected that 15 minor Labourite members in the House of Commons will join the Liberal Labourite party in view of the socialistic resolutions passed at the Hull Con- ference ( Reuter)

div.head: ENGLAND AND CHINA
div.p: The “Times” learns from Hong Kong that the British gunboats have been withdrawn from the West River and patrolling has ceasesed, all the conditions required by England before the withdrawal having been satisfied, including payment of an indemnity (Reuter )

div.head: THE PREMIER ILL
div.p: Sir H Campbell Bannerman is confined to his room with a chill and was unable to attend the Privy Council held at Windsor to consider the King’s Speech (Reuter )

div.head: GERMANY AND ABYSSINA.
div.p: The “Cologne Gazette” protests strongly against the article in the “Standard” stating that the Holtz mission to Abyssinia is in connection with the German Government. ‘This news, it says, is entirely without foundation Reuter

div.head: THE GENERAL DEPRESSION
div.p: Mr. Lloyd George, speaking at Cardiff, said that the depression in the United States and Germany was likely to spread to Great Britain but he was confident that it would not be severe ( Reuter

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.byline: We do not bold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex Proased by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit—within certain necessary limite— free discusssion.

div.head: PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
div.p: Sir,—Your recent article on the present plight of the Party of the People explains the state of affairs in a nutshell. As an example of what native opinion on this subject is, I send you the following article from “Al Watan,” which explains the position most impartially :

“The recent split in the ranks of the Party of the People is a most regrettable event. It is, at the same time, a typical Egyptian ocour- rence in such cases illustrative of the real mo tives and the real powers which bave to be taken intoaccount when politieal parties are to be created and coustructed in this land “Al Garida,” the organ of the party which was founded by a select number of our potables j and leaders of thought, has served the purpose f that party in the most faithfull and straight forward manner, always advpoating the cause of the people against the ruling powers. It repeatedly explained in the most explicit and conscieatious manner that the two powers now ruling Egypt, the Khedive and the British xecupation, may have aims and interests at times not identical with the interests of the people to which it devoted all its energies at all times. This, of did not please everybody and the usual intrigues began to work, ending in the last schism and the disa- vowal or ‘Al Garida” by many Pashas and Beys who belped to found it a year ago on the ground that the said newspaper had unneces sarily criticised certain officials of the Palace and advocated acavse other than of his Highiess the Khedive. Tha disenssion of Fs question bas been long and painful and the victory rested with the party known as the “Reform League.’ It is worthy of note, however, that all the notables who have dis avowed “Al Garida” and its principle of serv ing the people are among those who clamonu fora Constitution on republican or democratic lines
The truth of these statements of “Al Watan cannot be denied by anyone with thé sligh test reward for the truth
Truly Yours
A Native Reader

div.byline: To THE Editor oF The Egyptian Gazette.”
div.p: With reference to what was written in your last issue about the “Party of the People, 1 am sorry to say that you must have been misled concerning facts to such an extent that you find everything distorted and in correct. Not a particle of truth lies in deserib- ing the unimportant dissensions in the Party as “terrific internecine struggles” nor in what you call “serious secession.”

Moreover Lord Cromer departed from Egypt about the middle of April last, and the Party was only proclaimed late in September , so there is no truth in your insinuation (in its worst seuse) that “as soon as Lord Cromer departed this ‘Party of the people” entirely changed its programme The Party has got only one programme which was announced on the 21st of September last, and since then no modifications have been therein introduced

Finally I see no alternative, as a gentleman, but to pass overall that you say about the party's " disregard for political consistency and its “acrimonious virulence towards Lord Cromer and the Occupation’ ete.ete, as show ing utter ignorance of facts and of what is going on in the broad daylight
Yours truly,
N. SHEHYNE

The statement that, in as much as the Party of the People was only constituted in the Autumn, therefore it could not have had any connection with The Lord Cromer is absurd. The Nationalist Party was only organized quite recently but it has existed for sone time past, and, as is well known the Party of the People owes its inception to the late Sheiki Mobamed Abdou and may be said to have commenced its actual existence with the first number, of ‘‘Al Garidah.’ Why the various parties have only been actually constituted since Lord Cromer's departure is said to be due to the crisis I the Cairo correspondent of the “Times" re- marks: -

Somewhat late in the day the various Egyp tian parties have realized the necessity of or- ganising themselves, and important meetings have recently been held by the “Nationalist” faction under Mustapha Pasha Kamel and the “Perty of Constitutional Reform” led by his rival, Sheikh Ali Youssef, at which the statutes of the “Egyptian National party” and the Constitutional Reform League” were read and adopted. This new departure is, I believe; to be explained in part by the action of the “Party of the people,” in part by the per sistence of an unfavourable financial situation Till recently many of the leading Nationalists were dependent for the funds which they required for journeys to Europe, political pro- paganda, Xc., on the generosity of a limited number of wealthy Turks and Egyptians, some of them discontented with the existing régime, others good easy men who bad a strong aversion to seeing their names in print, unless accompanied by eulogies ot the most trident pitch, or desired to maintain or acquire a repu tation for generosity. The financial crisis has closed many purses, and it has become neces sary to appeal for aid to the Egyptian public, a course which has met with the warm ap proval of certain disinterested Nationalists who have good reason to dislike a system which has rendered their political activity dependent on the munificence of a few notables or of the

Palace. Whether their optimistic views con cerning the support which will be given by the public to an appeal for wabsoriptions in aid of party funds is likely to be justified or not is another question. The ntasses, in my opinion, in the absence of any religions or economic stimulus, will long remain profoundly indif ferent.

div.head: ZAGAZIG RACES
div.p: A Zagazig correspondent sends us the follow ing account of the races there, the results of which were given yur issne of Saturday last

The second winter meeting of the Zagazig Racing Club took place on Friday, the 24th inst before a very attendance. The racing was extremely good, the principal race of the day resulting in a dead heal Considerable improvements have been effected since last meeting, the paddock has been enlarged anda fifth stand erected besides a weighing room, and stewards room. As no special train arrangements had been marie there were not many visitors trom Cairo.

Among those present were the Governor ot Port Said, Omar Bey Sultan, Ahmed Key Bukni, Ahmed Bey Fathi, Messre. de Freville, Moberley, Burnett Stewart, Hopkins, Camper and Blomfield escorting some visitors from Mena House. Among the ladies we noticed many charming to'letes which we regret we are unable to describe
In addition to those already mentioned were present Mr and Mra Hoalm, Mr and Mrs MacLaren, Mr. and Mre Peach, Mr. and Mra Dray, Messrs. Wild, Trydel!, Ireland ('Sulli van, Cremer Roberts, and Wallis

Both the owner and trainer of Speculaticr are to be congratulated on the splendid form shown by this horse, who undoubtedly poands above his recent Cairo form, and in the hands of Bonsor made a dead heat and a win besides a second with a native boy op
The camel race ax usual created great interest the winner though handicapped 30 metres won in a canter literally and ia undoubtediy a magnificent animal, possibly the best in Egypt.

div.head: AN EXCELLENT SEASON.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent)
Assouan, 22nd January
Prince Waldemar of Prussia arrived at the Savoy Hotel on Monday by the Hamburg and Anglo American steamer ‘Mayflower’ and will stay here till the end of Febroary

Prince George of Cumberland, often ca!led the Duke of Brunswick, makes the Savoy his winter home and so does Sir Stephen Macken sie, Who las spent no less than eight winters at Assouan, and appreciates the quiet and re tirement of Elepbantine Island.
‘There are many new names on the visitors list of the Cataract Hotel a}ich is @ very long one considering theery everywhere ot a ‘bad season.”
Among the latest arrivals are His Excellency Fakri Pasha, Mr. Richard Croker the well j known American of racing fame, Mr. ‘I’, Gibson Bowles, MP, Sir George Lambert, and Connt Irenbery.

A very successful dance was given on the Lath inst. in the beautiful Arabian dining hall which is such a feature of the Cataract Hotel. Many people came trou the steamers “Paritan” and “Amasis” wicli were lying at Assouan and the scene was a very animated one ‘hore was also a dance at the Savoy last vcek and a gymkha- pa in the great ¢ urtyard of the Cataract Ho- tel on the i7th inst. with donkey races tor ladies and gentlemen.

Donkey riding ploy. no sinall part in the ple asures of a winter in Egypt bic the ill treat nent the poor animals often receive isa : of groat regret to all lovers of animals. The So eiety for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals hae branches both at) Assonan ane! Loxor and their stables where sick donkeys or those suffer ing fromaill usage are taken in and properly cared foc hy @ native veteiuary surgeon are worth a visit Mro Ho Pembroke, a well known winter resident of A-souan is the Honorary Se- cretary and devutes a greac deal of his time to the work of the Society |
The sailing at Assonan is qnite good and re gattas take pauiee several times during the season
Rridge helds its own as an evening amuse ment at the Assouan Hotels and a bridge tournamentin which a large number of visitors took part took place at the Cataract on the evening of the goth. inst

Some anxiety was feltearlior in the season st the tresh cracks in the wails of the English ehureh, due ta the aking of the ground on which itis tuilt Energetic measures bave been taken te repair the muschiet and otis hoped it will not) ge any further, The Venerable Arch Spens, Who suceeeded Bishop 7 aplain, resides in the Charch House, but always lonches and dines at the Cataract Hotel Both Mr and Mrs Spens are already well known and much liked at Assouan as they were at Caux, where Archdeacon Spens was chaplain for many years before coming to Egypt. Visitors to that popular Swiss resort will recall the beautiful new chureh that bas just been erected there, thanks to the Arch deacons active instromentality. Mrs Lowe,and her Son, Mr Mackinsee Lowe, are among the oldest winter residents of Asscuan, and the very few who rent villas All the celebrities who visit Assousn are to be metat Me. Lowe's house. Dr Cannes t. also as popular host who gives many delightful tea parties and brings people together His book or the climate of | Rgypt swell worth stedying by new 3 | especially health scekers for ne gives many usetul hints how to keep weil and avoid the elalls that are easy eaught eves in such tsplenditclimate ss that of Upper Egy pt his advice moreover is founded on wide experience gained by many years residence here and careful study and comparison of various seasons in Egypt
THE GRAND HOTEL
Another correspondent writes

The tourist) season of Assonan has received vudeitional impetus by the opening of the Grand Hertel This bestelry situated in the heart of the town, which by the way was i first hotel in Assonai is bow beginning to fill. No doubt the reasonable charges suitable (o all pockets and its central position have a good deal to do with its populsrity, It has the ad- vantage of being within three minutes from the station and two minutes from the landing stages of the steamers Among its guests are Mr and Mrs. Shadwell, Count and Countess Hamilton, Mr. L. To THE SHAREHOLDERS OF
The Commercial Industrial and
Land Company of Egypt, Limited,

Since the circular dated (5th January 1908 of the Directors to the Shareholders was issued | Mr. W. Ablitt in pursuance of Article 64 of the Articles of Association which is simply a pro- vision enacted by the Companies Act 1900), and in continuation of the policy of wrecking the Compeny which he has apparently adopted, has through his Solicitors served the Directors with a requisition requiring them to convene | an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Mem- bers of the Company for the purpose of consi- dering and if thought fit passing the following resolution
“Mhat the Company be wound up voluntati ly and that Mr. Arnold Francis Dickin of 9 and 10 Pancras Lane in the City of London, ‘Chartered Accountant, be appointed Liquida- tor thereof.”

In compliance with this Requisition the Di rectors have decided themselves to convene the Meeting which is to he held on the 6ch Fe bruary 1908 for the purpose of considering the resolution in question rather than allow the re. juisitionists to do so which otherwise they would have been entitied to do

The utter disragard of the interests of the shareholders who have subscribed to the funds of the Company shewn by the persc” who was the Vendor to the Company of the business which forms its chief asset and pone of whase bave been paid for in cash can ouly be ascribed to personal feeling arising from his Msmissal trom the post of Manager, or to the hope of getting back the business into his own possession now that a large portion of the sabs ed money has been expended on the same as therefore the Shareholders take enorge steps to frustrate this wanton aud injastifia ble attempt to wreck the Corpany the value ot their holdings will be seriously diminished, if not absolutely destroyed

the Directors therefore car only urge upon Shareholders the necessity in their own in f attending the Meeting, formal notice f which has been only given, and voting against the resolutions to wind up. Should members however be unable to attend person- | ally and vote against the resolution they are requested to sign @ proxy without delay, whiob an be obtained at the offices of Messrs. Rus sell, Kerr and Wyatt,Sharia Kasr-e!-Nil, Cairo, and must be left with them

Rearers of Shane Warrants who wish to vote j at the Meeting must elso deposit their War rants until after sach Meeting at the offices of Messrs. Russell Kerr and Wyatt, Sharia Kasr Nil, Cairo who will hand them a certificate in exchange
Dated this 21st day of January 1908
By order of the Board
Acting Secretary
N.B.— Proxies and Share Warrants should he deposited at the offices of Messrs. Russell, Kerrand Wyatt, Sharia Kasr-el Nil, Cairo, not later than January 28th. 1905
The Commercial Industrial and Land Co. of Egypt Ltd.

There seems to be great misconception as the Meeting to be held in London on Febru ary 6th tor the purpose of considering a | Resolution that has been brought forward to | wind up the company. Mr. Walt-r Ablitt is | responsible for the Resolution and the Di \ rectors are against its adoption in as much as they believe it to be contrary to the inte rests of the shareholders as a body feeling “confident that if properly managed and con lucted the business of R Kuster and Co belonging tu the Company, of which Mr. Ablitt bas unul recently had the ma agement, will show a substantial returo on the amount of | capital invested |

The Accounts presented at the Annual Meeting of tbe Company on 13 January, | audited by Messrs. Russell Kerr and Wyatt, as at 30 Jone 1907. show that the total profit | earned by the compan) from its incorporation April 12 1906) to June 80 1907, was £7,700 of which £ 524 was earned by the business of R. Kuster & (Co. ~All the profit hae been arried forward.-The share capital consists of 98,977 Ordinary Shares of £ 1 anc 5,000 Deferred Shares of £ leach ; o1 the former of which the sum of £8,803 remains out steuding. The Assets are shown as £ 200,000, of which £ 147,000 i2 stock and work in | progress, sundrf debtors aod bills reoeiyable whilst cash in hand, buildings, office furnitare, land ete. represent £ 17,700. During the year 1908, cash amounting to upwards of £ 16,000 will be received by the company in respect of the sale of land to the Egyptian Improvements Corporation
The total value of the assets must be seri sly affected by sny compulsory realisation f and to avert this end shareholders are earnestly invited to vote against the Resolution for Liquidation
Proxies can be obtained at the offices of Messrs Russell Kerr and Wyatt, Kaar et-Nil, Cairo, and must be left there not tater than Wednesday next January 29th. Holders of
must also deposit the warrants at Messrs Russel Kerr and Wyatt until after the meeting.

Shareholders are advised to withdraw im- mediately all proxies given to third parties and to support the Board in the continuance | of a policy which should next year result in substantial profits to the Company.
By order Avrrep Bunaury Seoretary Maison Chawarbi Pusha, Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.
Jemaary 25 1905.
